article.description: Sam Cassell scored 11 of his 26 points in the opening 12 minutes against his former team as the Milwaukee Bucks rode a hot first quarter to a 95-79 rout of the New Jersey Nets.
article.headline: Bucks win second straight without coach Karl
article.linkText: Cassell's quick start propels Bucks past Nets
article.story:
MILWAUKEE (AP) -- The Milwaukee Bucks followed Sam Cassell's lead.
Cassell

Cassell had a season-high 28 points and six assists, and Ray Allen added 21 points and a season-high eight rebounds, leading Milwaukee to a 95-79 victory over the New Jersey Nets on Saturday night, the Bucks' second game without coach George Karl. Jason Kidd, who had 14 points and six assist for the Nets, said the Bucks fed off Cassell's scoring and energy. "He's the catalyst for that team," Kidd said of Cassell. "When he goes, they go. It seemed like he made every shot tonight." Keith Van Horn scored 15 points for the Nets, who had their lowest point total of the season. New Jersey scored 82 points in a loss at home to Philadelphia on Nov. 17. The Nets' Kerry Kittles finished with five points, seven points below his average. Terry Stotts assumed the head coaching duties for just the third time in nine seasons as an NBA assistant coach and second straight game. Karl was in the Seattle area for the funeral of his father, Joseph, who died Thursday morning. He will be back for practice Monday. In their first game under Stotts, the Bucks snapped their five-game losing streak, their longest in two seasons, with a victory at home Thursday night against Toronto. Several Milwaukee players credited Stotts' low-key approach for allowing helped the team relax and regain its composure, despite blowing an 18-point lead. "Sam's last two games, he's really been a good leader for us," Stotts said. "He always says as he goes, the team goes. I think there's some truth to that." Cassell had 13 points and two assists in the third quarter as the Bucks maintained their double-digit lead. His 3-pointer just before the end of the quarter gave Milwaukee an 80-61 lead. Milwaukee coach Byron Scott rested his starters and played the reserves in the final quarter. Lucious Harris hit consecutive 3-pointers midway through the fourth to trim the Bucks' lead to 86-71. It was as close as New Jersey would get as Tim Thomas, who had 12 points, stopped the comeback attempt with a driving layup. The Nets shot 33.3 percent (30-for-90) from the field. The Bucks shot 48.8 percent (41-for-84). The Bucks outscored the Nets 30-17 in the first quarter, sparked by 11 points from Cassell, who hit 13 of 21 shots in the game. The Nets never recovered. "Tonight, we came out ready to play," said Glenn Robinson who had 13 points and five rebounds. "Everybody had their shot going, we were rebounding as a team, we didn't let them get any of their tricks, like the backdoors and cuts." Milwaukee, led by a season-high 18 rebounds from Ervin Johnson, controlled the boards. The Bucks had 57 to New Jersey's 43. Anthony Mason added 12 boards for the Bucks. Todd MacCulloch scored 13 points and led the Nets with six rebounds. At 12-7, the Nets are still off to their best start since joining the league in 1976. Allen, who had 12 points in the first half, hit a 3-pointer that closed out the second quarter and gave the Bucks a 53-37 lead.

Game notes
Milwaukee shot 51.1 percent (24-47) from the floor to 32.7 percent (16-49) for the Nets in the first half. ... Forward Jason Caffey was not in uniform for the Bucks because of a strained left hip flexor. ... The Nets have started the same five players, who are averaging double-figures in scoring, for all 19 games this season. ... The Bucks swept the Nets (4-0) last season for the first time in 11 seasons and just the second time since New Jersey entered the NBA in 1976-'77. ...

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.
